intro: Abelia serrata var. buchwaldii, commonly known as the Buchwald abelia, is a deciduous shrub native to eastern Asia. It features showy, tubular pink to white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has glossy, ovate leaves with serrated edges, giving it a distinctive appearance. It thrives in partial shade to full sun and prefers well-drained soil. This variety is prized for its ornamental value and adaptability to various garden conditions.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abelia serrata var. buchwaldii is primarily native to China, specifically the provinces of Hubei, Sichuan, and Yunnan. This variant is found in mountainous regions at elevations ranging from 1,000 to 2,500 meters. It thrives in humid, temperate climates with well-drained soil. The plant is often found in forests and along stream banks. It is known for its attractive, fragrant flowers and is sometimes cultivated as an ornamental plant.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abelia serrata var. buchwaldii was mainly introduced to the Pacific Northwest region of the United States. It is commonly found in moist, well-drained soils in shaded to partially shaded environments. This variety is valued for its ornamental qualities, including its fragrant flowers and attractive foliage. It has been widely cultivated in gardens and landscapes due to its hardiness and adaptability. However, it is important to note that it may spread aggressively in natural areas if not properly managed.
